ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

STAGNATED TEACHERS WITH TEN YEARS' CONTINUOUS SERVICE
(Emplacement on salary scale for Education Officer, Group III)


    1. Encik Sidek bin Saniff asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Education if he will consider the emplacement of those stagnated teachers, who have done ten years' continuous service in the teaching Profession, on the salary scale for Education Officer, Group III.

     The Minister for Home Affairs and Education (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, teachers whose salaries stagnate at certain points on the Education Officer/Group III (EO/III) salary scale are either untrained or under-qualified. Among the teachers considered under-qualified are those trained under other schemes. For those untrained they may be considered for full emplacement on the EO/III salary scale if they obtain a Certificate-in-Education through part-time studies at the Institute of Education. For the under-qualified and the trained under other schemes teachers they may be considered for full emplacement on the EO/III salary scale if they had completed 10 years' service and found suitable through interviews. Such under-qualified and trained under other schemes teachers may also be considered for full emplacement on the EO/III salary scale if they had 10 years' service and obtained three GCE 'O' level passes, one of which must be the language of instruction.

    As there are adequate avenues for teachers stagnated at certain points on the EO/III salary scale to be fully emplaced at that salary scale, my Ministry does not consider it appropriate to emplace such teachers fully on 10 years' continuous service alone.

     Encik Sidek bin Saniff (Kolam Ayer): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would be most grateful if the Minister could enlighten the House as to how many teachers in this category were

Column: 370

involved, how many of them got through and were emplaced on the EO/III salary scale ($1,030) by the Public Service Commission after an interview, and how many of them through self-development.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, there were originally 1,439 teachers in this category. Of this number, 1,003 were emplaced after an interview and 203 were emplaced after they had obtained three 'O' level passes. To-date there are 1,206 such teachers who have been emplaced on the EO/III salary scale. There are now still stagnating 233 teachers.

     Encik Sidek bin Saniff: Mr Speaker, Sir, the figures show that there is only about one per cent of the total teaching population who have not been emplaced in the EO/III salary scale. It is about 50%, in fact not even halt compared to those who have been promoted recently in the promotion exercise. I would suggest to the Minister that he should discuss with the Minister for Finance, and not to pass the buck, that these teachers should be seriously considered for emplacement on the EO/III salary scale, say, on the basis of 12 or even 15 years of service.

    My argument is this. Would the Minister agree that even if these teachers were emplaced on the EO/III salary scale, not all of them, that is, the 200-odd teachers, would reach the maximum of their salary scale when they reach the age of retirement? As we have always been talking about respecting our elders, would the Minister agree that here is an avenue where we can prove that we really appreciate our elders. This lot of teachers are among the elders in the teaching profession, and they have contributed immensely to the teaching profession.

    Would the Minister also agree that by emplacing them on the EO/III salary scale, we can save them embarrassment or even nightmare, as put by one teacher by the surname of Lim who wrote to me hoping very much that a new deal could be given to them. We could once and for all erase these 200-odd "untouchables" of the teaching

Column: 371

profession. Even the untouchables have every expectation in their next incarnation - Shudrah, Waisya, Ksatria or even Brahmin.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I say that the teachers are certainly not considered "untouchables." In fact, in my answer just now, I have said that there are now adequate avenues whereby these teachers can be emplaced on the EO/III salary scale. In fact, out of 1,439 such teachers, 1,206 have already been emplaced through these avenues. There is no reason why the rest of them cannot be emplaced through these avenues. I do not think the Ministry can do more than what has already been done.

     Encik Sidek bin Saniff: Mr Speaker, Sir, most of the teachers, that is, more than 1,000 of them, have been emplaced through self-development, i.e. they have obtained three 'O' level passes, and not through interviews by the PSC. Secondly, these teachers are getting old. Age can sometimes catch up with a person and there is then no more vigour to learn. That is why I would like the Minister to consider, in conjunction with the Ministry of Finance, whether a continuous service of 12 years or even 15 years will be given consideration in future.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, my reply is that we would certainly like to encourage these teachers to develop themselves further. It is good for the Ministry to encourage them to self-develop, and the Ministry can recognise it by emplacing them on a higher salary scale through the present avenues.

     Mr Sia Khoon Seong (Moulmein): Mr Speaker, Sir, would the Minister be able to say how many teachers from the English stream are in this category, as my union would be interested in helping them?

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not able to give details as to how many of them are from the Malay stream, English stream or the Chinese stream. If the Member for Moulmein is interested, I shall supply him with the particulars.

PRIMARY AND SECONDARY
SCHOOLS AND JUNIOR COLLEGES
(Library facilities)


    2. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Education whether he is aware that library facilities in primary and secondary schools and junior colleges are inadequate and if he will take steps to improve them.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the library facilities in schools are being developed and improved upon. This will have to be carried out in stages. For existing schools, a programme has been initiated for both the extension of physical facilities and the improvement of book collection. In January 1977, the Ministry implemented a School Library Development Project whereby library grants were made available to all existing primary schools to establish central libraries and to all secondary schools which need to expand their library facilities.

    For new schools, plans have been incorporated in their designs to set up fully-equipped central libraries. Besides the improvement in the physical facilities, the Ministry is rendering services to the schools by training the school library co-ordinators to improve their skills in the running of school libraries. With the flexibility now granted on the use of School Funds, principals may exercise their discretion to use the Funds for library development.

Column: 372

CONFIRMATION OF SERVICE OF TEACHERS
(Policy)


    3. Mr Sia Khoon Seong asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Education whether his Ministry will review its present policy of requiring teachers seeking confirmation of service to pass Malay Standard 1, and whether equivalent qualification in Chinese, Tamil or English will also be deemed acceptable, so that a teacher, seeking confirmation, can offer in addition to his first language qualification one of the remaining three languages as the additional language requirement.

Column: 373



     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ministry of Education is reviewing the Education Scheme of Service and the requirement to pass Malay Standard I for confirmation is one of the matters in the Scheme which is under review.

    At present, Government officers in the Education Service are required to pass Malay Standard I for confirmation. This cannot be substituted by another official language. However, the requirement to pass Malay may be waived if the work and conduct of the teachers during their probation have been very good.

Column: 373

TRANSFER OF TEACHERS
(Particulars)


    4. Mr Sia Khoon Seong asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Education (a) how many teachers were transferred in the last three months; (b) how many of those transferred had not asked for transfer themselves and what was the basis of selection of such teachers for transfer; (c) how many of those who had asked for transfer were not transferred; and (d) how many were transferred to schools more than 10 kilometres from their homes.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of teachers transferred in the last three months was 1,567 and out of this number 1,001 teachers were transferred owing to necessity and not because they had applied for transfer. It is not possible to consider all requests for transfer. Some teachers do not meet the requirements of the schools to which they wish to be transferred or the schools in question do not have vacancies to be filled.

    Generally, the factors taken into consideration when selecting teachers for transfer are -

    (i) matching of the specific needs of receiving schools to the teachers' teaching subjects and language of instruction;

    (ii) the ability of the sending schools to release the teachers - in cases where teachers are key digits, the schools are reluctant to release them; and

Column: 374



    (iii) proximity of teachers' homes to schools.

    The number of teachers who applied for transfer in the last three months but who were not transferred was 873.

    The number of teachers who were transferred to schools more than 10 km from their homes in the last three months was 267.

    While every effort is made to post teachers to schools as close to their homes as possible, it must be appreciated that often teachers may be posted to schools which are 6 km or more from their homes. This is because in certain areas such as Katong and Marine Parade there is an over abundance of teacher; living there in relation to the available posts while in places like Jurong and Lim Chu Kang there are far more teaching posts available than there are teachers living there. Other factors such as matching the teachers' own abilities and preferences to the schools' requirements add to this problem.

Column: 374

RETRENCHED CLERICAL
EMPLOYEES OF CHINESE
RURAL SCHOOLS
(Alternative employment)


    5. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Education (a) how many clerical employees of some aided Chinese schools in the rural area have become unemployed following the closure of the schools recently; (b) why the Ministry of Education cannot employ them in some of the schools which have newly been opened; and (c) whether an assurance can be given to similar employees of schools which are still functioning that they will not suffer the same fate if their schools are closed, as they have been feeling insecure and demoralised since the retrenchments.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, in 1976, six clerks were rendered redundant. Three were given alternative postings to other Government-aided schools where vacancies existed. One refused redeployment and two had their services terminated because they could not be redeployed.

Column: 375



    In 1977, although nine aided Chinese schools closed down, only two clerks were rendered redundant. The two clerks were redeployed to other Government-aided schools.

    The Ministry helps to redeploy the clerks by posting them to other aided schools where vacancies exist. Where no such vacancies exist and the clerks meet the minimum educational qualifications for appointment to the Government General Clerical Service, their cases are referred to the Ministry of Finance and the Public Service Commission for absorption into the General Clerical Service to serve in the newly opened Government schools. In the event they cannot be absorbed into the General Clerical Service, their services have to be terminated. Every possible assistance has been and will continue to be given by my Ministry to redeploy the redundant aided school clerks.

     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Sir, the Minister has not answered the most important part of my question. Can the Minister give an assurance whether similar employees of schools which are still functioning will not suffer the same fate if their schools are closed down? I insist upon an assurance from the Minister because employees of Chinese-aided schools are between 45 and 50 years old and the employment market for this age-group is very thin.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, although the assurance has not been specifically spelt out, the fact that the Ministry is doing its best to redeploy some of these redundant school clerks is itself concrete evidence of what the Ministry is doing. That, Mr Speaker, Sir, is better than a specific assurance from the Ministry. What the Ministry has done for these redundant clerks, to my mind, is a better assurance than any statement by the Ministry.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, Sir, just now the Minister said that in 1976 two clerical employees had their services

Column: 376

prematurely terminated because jobs could not be found for them.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, the Ministry can only give an assurance that it will do its best to redeploy these clerks. It cannot guarantee them a job. I do not think the Ministry can guarantee that these clerks who have been found redundant will be given jobs. The Ministry can only try to do its best and has done what it could for these clerks.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, is the Minister aware that if the Government had not taken over these aided Chinese schools, in the event of retrenchment these clerks would have been paid retrenchment benefits?

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, these clerks who are affected are from Government aided schools. The Government has not taken over the schools. It is still aiding these schools. In fact, the clerks are employed by the aided schools. They are not employed by the Government. So the question as to whether the Government has taken over or has not taken over the aided schools does not arise. The Member for Khe Bong should know that, as far as clerks in Government schools are concerned, they are recruited by the Public Service Commission and they must satisfy the requirements of the Government General Clerical Service. But in this case these clerks are employees of the aided schools and they are still the responsibility of the aided schools. Whether they are given retrenchment benefits or not, it is not the responsibility of the Government. It is the responsibility of the aided schools.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, Sir, are you denying that they are on the payroll of the Government?

     Mr Speaker: Mr Ho, are you addressing that question to me?

     Mr Ho See Beng: I am sorry, Sir. The question is addressed to the Minister.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, I will answer that question. The fact that they are on the payroll of the Government does not mean that they are in the service of the Government as in the case of the employees in Government schools.

Column: 377



     Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, I want to ask the Minister whether the Ministry of Education has the right to hire and fire these employees.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, the aided school board has the right to hire and fire these aided school employees.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Is it not the same? The school board has the right to hire and fire. When it comes to the question of payment of retrenchment benefits, they say that this is not the responsibility of the Government.

     Mr Speaker: Mr Ho, the Minister has already answered your question.

LEAVE ALLOWANCES
(Request for revision)


    6. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Finance, in view of the consolidation of 1973-77 National Wages Council allowances into salary scales for civil servants, if he will consider revising the existing fixed leave allowances under the 1973 Leave Scheme.

     The Senior Minister of State for Finance (Mr Goh Chok Tong) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, when the Civil Service Leave Scheme was amended in 1973 to allow civil servants to commute their vacation and medical leave into pay, the matter was discussed with unions representing the public service. Explicit agreement was reached that the rates of leave allowances would remain fixed and unchanged, notwithstanding any subsequent general salary revisions. The compensation for deducted vacation leave was at the rate of one day's pay for each day of vacation leave whilst for medical leave, the rate of one day's pay for six days medical leave. The quantum of leave allowance, using the factor of 286 work:ing days per year, worked out to percentages of salary, ranging from 6% to 10% for Division I to Division IV officers.

    This Leave Scheme was effective from January 1973. The first payment of NWC allowances was in July 1973. Hence, NWC allowances did not feature in the computation of the Scheme.

Column: 378



    I think it would be wrong to revise the leave allowances with every revision of salaries. It would leave the matter open for all time and place an onerous liability on public funds. My Ministry is therefore not prepared to consider any revision of leave allowances under the 1973 Leave Scheme.

     Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Hon. Senior Minister of State explained that it would be wrong to revise the leave allowances, and I think it is right. But I want to know why newly recruited clerks are getting $30 leave allowance when the old clerks are getting only $20. Can the Senior Minister of State enlighten me on this?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Sir, I am not aware that newly recruited clerks are given $30 leave allowance while old ones are given $20 leave allowance. I thought that the quantum of compensation was fixed in 1973 and new recruits are given the option to either opt for the old scheme including the leave eligibility applicable under the old scheme or the new scheme with the leave allowances fixed in 1973.

     Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, I do understand what it means. But I am talking about a situation where there could be an anomaly between the leave allowances paid to new clerks and old clerks. That is the reason why I have tabled the question on whether the Minister will consider revising the leave allowances.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Sir, as I said, I am not aware that there is an anomaly. But nevertheless to satisfy the Member for Anson, I will look into the matter and see whether there is such an anomaly.

TRADE DEVELOPMENT COUNCIL
(Formation)


    7. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister for Finance whether a decision has now been taken on the formation of the proposed Trade Development Council and, if not, why not.

Column: 379



     Mr Goh Chok Tong (for the Minister for Finance): Sir, the Government is currently holding discussions with representatives of the various Chambers of Commerce and Industry and Singapore Manufacturers' Association on the setting up of the Trade Development Council. These discussions will include the form that the Trade Development Council should take and the financial and operational aspects of the Council. These have to be thoroughly evaluated to ensure that the Council, when formed, will begin on a proper and effective footing. A properly organised and operated Trade Development Council should be of great help in promoting exports from Singapore. In this connection, the Government believes that to ensure the success of the Council, the private sector must be closely involved both in funding as well as in the running of the Council. Indeed, one of the main reasons for setting up the Trade Development Council must be that it will receive the benefit of private enterprise and initiative.

Column: 379

NON-WORKING RETIRED PERSONS
(Exemption from income tax)


    8. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Finance if he will consider introducing amending legislation to exempt non-working retired persons from income tax as this will enable the Government indirectly to look after their welfare during retirement.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong (for the Minister for Finance): Sir, for resident pensioners, some measure of relief is already provided since half of the pension is tax exempt. However, a non-working retired person may also derive substantial investment income in the form of dividends, interest, rents and so on. If such a person were exempted from paying income tax, he would be better off than another person who has to continue working after reaching normal retirement age because of financial needs. To encourage pensioners to continue working, our tax laws provide enhanced relief for them. Thus an individual who is above 55 but below 60 years of age is entitled to an earned income relief of $2,000, while an individual who has attained the age

Column: 380

of 60 will get a relief of $3,000 instead of the usual relief of $1,000. This has the effect of encouraging persons who attain normal retirement age to continue to be gainfully employed. The exemption of non-working retired persons would be contrary to the rationale behind the granting of enhanced earned income relief.

ECONOMIC ACTIVATION COMMITTEE
(Contribution towards economy)


    9. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Finance what the Economic Activation Committee has contributed towards the economy of the Republic since the formation of the Committee and to what extent it has assisted industries.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong (for the Minister for Finance): Sir, the Economic Activation Committee (EAC) was formed in November 1974. In the industrial sector, the EAC improved inter-Ministry coordination in matters such as planning approval, compliance with fire safety, environmental, anti-pollution and other requirements to facilitate speedy implementation of industrial investment projects in the Economic Development Board (EDB) pipeline.

    The EAC has also assisted industries by obtaining temporary exemption from the 10% tax on Public Utilities Board (PUB) bills for firms consuming between 100,000 to 400,000 megawatts of electricity monthly. This concession which is normally available to industries consuming more than 400,000 megawatts per month has been in effect since 1st April 1975. As at September 1977, 72 companies were enjoying this concession. In addition, more than 20 export oriented companies were granted waiver of the declared demand charge by the PUB between March 1975 to December 1976. The PUB has also adopted a scheme to spread out the payments for the maximum demand charge incurred during the first six months of operation of certain specialised energy-intensive industries such as foundries, electroplating and heat treatment plants.

    To stimulate the construction sector, the EAC has drawn up priority lists of public

Column: 381

sector projects for resettlement action in order that these projects could be speedily carried out. This has helped to maintain the momentum of public sector construction activity. To assist the private residential property sector, the Committee was instrumental in obtaining exemption from the Residential Property Act for foreigners purchasing apartments in blocks of flats of at least six storeys. This concession has also been extended to units in approved condominium developments. Furthermore, foreigners of economic benefit to Singapore are being liberally permitted to buy houses occupying up to 15,000 square feet of land for their own occupation in Singapore.

    To intensify Singapore's export promotion efforts, the EAC encouraged the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to open a special rediscount window for export bills. This came into operation on 1st May 1975 to provide cheaper financing for manufacturers and traders. $200 million was provided by the MAS to be rolled over every three months (or $800 million a year) at a preferential rate fixed at 7% in May 1975 and subsequently reduced in line with the falling interest rates to the present level of 3 1/2% The monthly average transactions for the last six months of 1977 was $108 million as compared to a total of $50 million in the first six months of the scheme. A further stimulus to export promotion was given with the incorporation of the Export Credit Insurance Corporation which commenced operation in August 1976 to protect Singapore exporters against a range of commercial and political risks. By December 1977, 127 policies with a total face value of $375 million had been issued. All in all, the EAC has been active.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Sir, does not the Senior Minister of State for Finance realise that by arranging for the PUB to grant tax exemption of usage of electricity by commercial firms, the Committee is encouraging the usage of energy in an era when everybody should be conscious of cutting down energy consumption?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Sir, I was merely replying to a question of the EAC's activity.

Column: 382



     Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, does the Senior Minister of State think that by that he has absolved himself from responsibility?

     Mr Speaker: Order. We will go on to the next question. Mr Tan.

CONCORDE SERVICE BETWEEN
LONDON AND SINGAPORE


    10. Mr Tan Soo Khoon asked the Minister for Finance (a) whether the short-lived Concorde service to London by Singapore Airlines has caused undue embarrassment and loss of prestige to SIA; (b) why SIA did not obtain clearance for flying the Concorde over foreign air space before entering into an agreement with British Airways to operate the Concorde; (c) how much money was spent by SIA in Singapore and abroad to publicise its Concorde service to London: and (d) what other financial repercussions are anticipated for SIA as a result of the cancellation of the service.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong (for the Minister for Finance): Sir, it is premature to refer to SIA's Concorde service as "short-lived" or "cancelled".

    The issue of traffic rights falls outside the province of my Ministry. Concorde overflight is a matter for the British and Malaysian authorities.

    Singapore Airlines does not believe it has suffered any "embarrassment" or "loss of prestige" from the suspension of Concorde services. It is a victim of circumstances. It will continue to improve air services into and out of Singapore for Singaporeans and other residents of the Asia-Pacific region.

    I am not prepared to answer the question on the amount of money spent by SIA on publicising its Concorde service. I hope that the hon. Member for Alexandra will understand the need for and respect the confidentiality of sensitive commercial and financial information of companies in Singapore, even if they are Government-owned.

Column: 383



     Mr Tan Soo Khoon (Alexandra): Sir, to announce with triumph, grandeur and lots of fanfare, the arrival of the supersonic service that would, in the Senior Minister of State's own words (Hansard, 9.11.97, col. 154), "position SIA firmly in the forefront of the airlines of the world", only to find out a short while later that all is not what was made out to be - if this has not been embarrassing enough to SIA, is it not a case of pulling wool over one's own eyes?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Sir, the question was whether SIA suffered any embarrassment. I have given my reply that SIA does not believe that it has suffered any embarrassment or loss of prestige. I think that should be good enough.

     Mr Tan Soo Khoon: Sir, I asked the Senior Minister of State whether it was a case of pulling wool over his own eyes. But since he cannot answer that question, I would like to move on to the next supplementary question.

    The Senior Minister of State seems to have evaded the salient point in this issue in his reply and, that is, as much as it was the job of the British Government to obtain clearance of foreign air space, was it also not the responsibility of SIA to ascertain that its partner in this joint venture was in a position to deliver the goods before signing a 10-year agreement?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Sir, the answer has been very explicit. That Concorde overflight is a matter for the British and Malaysian authorities.

     Mr Tan Soo Khoon: Sir, when the Hon. Senior Minister of State says that the financial losses are too sensitive, to be revealed, does he mean that the losses were therefore far from minimal?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Sir, that was never implied. What I have said was that commercial information is a matter of confidentiality for commercial companies and that I hope the Member for Alexandra would appreciate the need for such confidentiality of companies' financial data, even if they are Government-owned.

Column: 384
